tossups.question: English adventurer Thomas Stuckley died fighting for this country. In this country's War of Succession, the Prior of Crato was defeated at the Battle of Alcantara. This country defended its independence at the Battle of Aljubarrota. This country's King Sebastian was killed during the Battle of Alcacer Quibir. The minister Marquis de (*) Pombal helped model this country's capital. This country, which originally conquered Ceuta and Melila from Morocco, developed the caravel which enabled it to conquer Macau, Angola, and Mozambique. Henry the Navigator was from, for 10 points, what country whose capital is Lisbon

During this war, one character begins a "sexless" relationship with the socialist Willi at the Mashopi hotel. A soldier in this war has his boots taken and is forced to march in wooden clogs, leading to his death from gangrene. In the aftermath of this war, a character studying optometry is visited in a mental hospital by Valencia Merble, with whom he discusses the novels of an obscure science-fiction author. After discovering that (*) Orr has escaped this war, one character escapes to Sweden; that character was earlier stabbed by Nately's whore. During this war, the schoolteacher Edgar Derby is shot for "looting" a teapot. A food-shipping cartel is run by Milo Minderbinder during this war, during which Billy Pilgrim is kept in Slaughterhouse-Five. For 10 points, name this war, the setting of Catch-22.

Arm DDT is used to perform this process. Bunyan helps people perform this process by creating JSON files. In an April Fools prank, one form of this process was referenced by a feature called QuackOverflow; that process involves talking to an inanimate rubber duck. This process can involve stepping into or over (*) breakpoints. People performing this process may examine the call stack to find the line number where a syntax error may have occurred. The term for this process was coined when Grace Hopper removed a moth from the Mark II computer. For 10 points, name this process of removing mistakes from a computer program.
tossups.answer: debugging [accept descriptions like removing bugs or finding bugs or removing errors or finding errors in code or error trapping; accept rubber duck debugging; prompt on logging or printing errors or bugs]
tossups.answer_formatted: debugging [accept descriptions like removing bugs or finding bugs or removing errors or finding errors in code or error trapping; accept rubber duck debugging; prompt on logging or printing errors or bugs]

tossups.question: Near the beginning of this opera, one character speaks of an attempt to poison an Englishman's parrot with parsley; that character enters after two others cry "Down with the author!" In this opera, two characters kiss a ribbon and a pink bonnet as they think of their loves. One character in this opera blows out a candle and pockets a lost key to spend more time with another, leading him to sing the aria (*) "Che gelida manina." One character in this opera abandons her lover Alcindoro and sings a namesake waltz to regain Marcello's affection; that character is Musetta. At the end of this opera, Rodolfo begins to cry when Mimi dies from tuberculosis. This opera inspired the musical Rent. For 10 points, name this opera set in Paris' Latin Quarter, by Giacomo Puccini.

Gregory Stanton described these events as having "symbolization" as one of their ten stages. Samantha Power criticized the American response to these events in A Problem From Hell. Roméo Dallaire's book Shake Hands with the Devil analyzes the response to one of these events. A convention that aimed to prevent these events was pushed by (*) Raphael Lemkin, who named these events. An analyst who studied these events divided them into stages like "classification," "discrimination," and "dehumanization," before ending in "extermination" and "denial." That work was influenced by one of these in Rwanda against the Tutsi. For 10 points, name these mass killings of a targeted group of people, such as the Holocaust.

Jean Chardin published travelogues about this empire describing making jewelry in it. People from this empire gained access to religious sites in the Peace of Amasya. This empire described its capital as "half the world" in an alliterative saying. The philosopher Mulla Sadra worked under this empire. The last ruler of this dynasty was deposed by Nadir, who had put him on the throne. Military organizations that supported this empire were named for their (*) red caps; those were the Qizilbash. Because of a lack of advanced weapons, this empire lost the Battle of Chaldiran. Abbas the Great made Isfahan the capital of this empire. Ismail I founded this empire and led it to be Twelver Shia. For 10 points, name this Persian empire that repeatedly fought the Ottomans

In this play, a "wasting disease of the frontal lobes" and a "wonder drug" are given as definitions of ABMAPHID by one character who distrusts biologists because they are "rearranging our genes." A line from A Streetcar Named Desire is quoted by one character in this play when he appears with snapdragons. One character in this play recites the Libera Me while another speaks of a character who died when he (*) swerved to avoid a porcupine; that character is one couple's imaginary son. During this play's second act, "Walpurgisnacht," two couples play games like "get the guest." This play ends with one character repeating "I... am..." in response to the title question. For 10 points, name this play centering on the dysfunctional couple George and Martha, by Edward Albee.

A problem about this statement's triviality was solved by the Maccone-Pati relation. Earle Kennard noted that the canonical commutation relation implied this statement, since one form of this statement contains a one over 2i term and holds for any two conjugate variables. This statement can be explained by imagining a (*) microscope observing an electron and therefore changing its movement. In this statement, the product of two standard deviations, such as energy and time, must be greater than or equal to h-bar divided by 2. For 10 points, name this statement which states that a position and momentum cannot both be precisely known, named for a German physicist.
tossups.answer: Heisenberg uncertainty principle [accept either underlined part; accept "equation" or "relation" in place of principle]
tossups.answer_formatted: Heisenberg uncertainty principle [accept either underlined part; accept equation or relation" in place of principle]

tossups.question: The final movement of this work opens with the maestoso melody [read slowly] whole notes E-flat, F, half note G, quarter notes E flat-G, half notes D-G, played over block chords. An oft-repeated melody in this work opens with the notes [read slowly] G-F-B flat-C-F-D and is first presented in 5/4-6/4 mixed meter. A "Dance of Chickens in their Shells" in this work is followed by a section whose opening crescendo depicts the approach of an oxcart, (*) "Bydlo." Maurice Ravel's orchestration of this programmatic work uses an alto saxophone to depict a troubadour outside an "Old Castle." A "Promenade" theme is varied throughout this piano suite. Viktor Hartmann's paintings inspired, for 10 points, what suite by Modest Mussorgsky?

The mother of one figure in this religion had visions of the rising sun, a full moon, and a great fire. Right perception, right knowledge, and right faith are the "three jewels" of this religion. This religion believes that space, time, and the principle of motion are among the six eternal substances of the universe, which is made up of three worlds called lokas. Rishabhanatha and (*) Mahavira are two important figures in this religion.Two sects of this religion are the Digambara and Śvētāmbara, or "sky clad" and "white clad." 24 spiritual teachers called tirthankaras, are central to this religion. For 10 points, name this religion, which emerged alongside Buddhism in ancient India.

A leader of this country adopted a policy translated as "beans and bullets" to gain support for his government, which was opposed by the Guerrilla Army of the Poor, or the EGP. A leader of this country was targeted by Operation WASHTUB before being replaced by Carlos Castillo Armas. Rigoberta Menchu, an activist from this country, won the Nobel Peace Prize for supporting the (*) K'ich'e people here. A CIA-backed 1954 coup in this country, Operation PBSUCCESS, deposed its leader Jacobo Arbenz and made this country a "banana republic" dominated by the United Fruit Company. Tikal is one of many Mayan ruins in this country. For 10 points, name this country which borders Belize and Mexico

This author called the title object of one poem a "lovely seneschal" and an "exquisite grotesque"; that object "has watched me / through the shifting gloom." Another poem by this author opens by describing Charles Thomas Wooldridge with the line "He did not wear his scarlet coat." This poet wrote "some do it with a bitter look, some with a flattering word" in a poem ending "the (*) brave man does it with a kiss, the coward with a sword." This author declared "Each man kills the thing he loves" in a poem named for the place where he was imprisoned for homosexuality. For 10 points, name this Irish poet of "The Ballad of Reading Gaol" who also wrote The Picture of Dorian Gray.

It's not carbon or hydrogen, but the "cyclohexa" allotrope of this element exists in a chair conformation. An ion of this element is responsible for the deep blue color of lapis lazuli. An anion containing this element and oxygen is titrated against iodine in iodometry. This element is extracted by pumping superheated water into the ground in the (*) Frasch process. A diprotic acid of this element can be produced using a vanadium catalyst in the contact process. This element is added to rubber in vulcanization. This element is bonded to hydrogen in thiols. For 10 points, name this element responsible for the rotten smell of eggs with atomic number 16.

26 or so people have drowned in this state's Round Valley Reservoir, which was then labeled this state's Bermuda Triangle. The Kirkwood-Cohansey aquifer supplies water to much of this state. Perth Amboy and Asbury Park are two of the many beach towns on this state's coast. This state's northeast contains numerous palisades by a river near (*) Fort Lee. This state's south is dominated by Cape May. The Raritan river runs through the center of this state, where the Passaic and Hackensack rivers also meet. This state contains large pine barrens along the Garden State Parkway. The Delaware River forms most of the western border of this state. For 10 points, name this state home to Trenton and Newark

In one Japanese fairy tale, Urashima Taro saves the daughter of a deity of this domain from children, and receives a box which prevents him from aging as a reward. The goddess Rán is married to a deity of this domain who has 9 daughters. That god of this domain converses with Bragi in the Skaldskaparmal. This domain of (*) Aegir was home to a god who married the nymph Amphitrite and fathered Triton. Oddysseus incurs the wrath of that god after blinding that god's son, Polyphemus. That god also created horses and caused earthquakes with his trident. For 10 points, name this aquatic domain of Posiedon.

Daniel Burnham's plan to redesign this city called for a large urban park by its Twin Peaks and adding an Athenaeum. Lotta's Fountain served as a meeting place for residents of this city after a natural disaster. Mayor Eugene Schmitz led the dynamiting of much of this city. Records destroyed in this city helped many people bring over (*) "paper children." This city developed from the town of Yerba Buena as well as a military presidio. Large fires in this city devastated its Nob Hill district. A natural disaster in this city provided land to build Fisherman's Wharf and destroyed much of its historic Chinatown. For 10 points, name this Northern California city devastated by a 1906 earthquake.

A song written by this author contrasts a certain character's "red thoughts" with his white teeth. Two men hunting in a "forest of mixed growth" in the Carpathians are caught under a fallen beech tree in a story by this author; those men are the mortal enemies Znaeym and Gradwitz. Because he believes them to be "dashing and not very respectable," one character of this author decides that his Houdan hen is an anabaptist. In that story by this author, (*) Conradin butters a piece of toast while Mrs. de Ropp is killed by the title polecat. A story by this author ends by noting that Vera Sappleton's "specialty" is "romance at short notice." For 10 points, name this author of "Sredni Vashtar" and "The Open Window."

This compound is the substrate of a manganese containing metalloenzyme which cycles through the S0 to the S4 states. During the Krebs cycle, this compound is removed and then added in the conversion of citrate to isocitrate. Plants can uptake this compound through either the symplastic or apoplastic route, but it must pass through the (*) Casparian strip. The hormone ADH signals for reabsorption of this compound. Aquaporins facilitate the transport of this compound across a cell membrane. This compound is transported from the roots to the leaves by the xylem. For 10 points, name this compound which makes up most of the volume of the cytosol.

In a painting titled for an object of this color, the artist and his daughter Ida are depicted as tiny figures playing among some trees; in that painting, the artist's wife Bella Rosenfeld looks down and wears a titular collar of this color. Another painting titled for this color features a man with outstretched hands that wears a green robe, as well as soldiers with flags destroying houses on its left. A (*) synagogue is depicted burning on the right of a painting titled for this color in which a menorah is depicted at the feet of Jesus, who is shown as a Jewish martyr. This color titles a Marc Chagall "Crucifixion."  This color is "beaten" with the Red Wedge in a Soviet propaganda poster. For 10 points, name this color used to paint snow.
tossups.answer: white [accept Bella with White Collar; accept White Crucifixion; accept Beat the Whites with the Red Edge]
tossups.answer_formatted: white [accept Bella with White Collar; accept White Crucifixion; accept Beat the Whites with the Red Edge]
acceptable: Beat the Whites with the Red Edge

tossups.question: In 2011, Tom Brady told an alumni of this university that he was "watching over" two of his college teammates. While at this school, one person threw a stolen laptop out a dorm window and later transferred to Blinn College. Other former players from this university who had legal troubles include Janoris Jenkins and Aaron Hernandez. A quarterback from this university had (*) John 3:16 written on eye black and famously knelt in prayer before games. Steve Spurrier won a Heisman at this university and later coached at it. A quarterback from this university became a minor league player for the New York Mets before returning to this university's state in 2021 to play for the Jacksonville Jaguars. For 10 points, Tim Tebow attended what university in Gainesville whose mascot is the Gators

bonuses.leadin: Because he is mourning this person, the author of one poem decides to send his patron translations of Callimachus  "lest [they] think that [their] words...  have slipped perhaps from my mind to vagrant winds." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this person. In a poem on the death of this person, the author arrives at "these miserable funeral rites" so that he may "speak in vain to the silent ash."

Catullus addressed many of his poems to this woman, including one in which he begs for "a thousand kisses, then a hundred" from her. Another poem by Catullus depicts this woman playing with her pet sparrow.
This Italian poet of Il Canzoniere praised Catullus, along with Propertius and Tibullus, as one of the foremost love poets in his Triumphus Cupidinis.
answers: Gaius Valerius Catullus' brother [prompt on Catullus or brother, do NOT accept or prompt on "Gaius Valerius Catullus"]
Lesbia [prompt on Clodia Metelli with "What name was she given in the poetry of Catullus?"]
answers_formatted: Gaius Valerius Catullus' brother [prompt on Catullus or brother, do NOT accept or prompt on "Gaius Valerius Catullus]
Lesbia [prompt on Clodia Metelli with "What name was she given in the poetry of Catullus?]
promptable: Clodia Metelli with "What name was she given in the poetry of Catullus?

bonuses.leadin: The first one of these things was created in 1796 by Edward Jenner to protect people from smallpox. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these things. Examples of these things used to provide immunity against COVID-19 are made by Pfizer and Moderna.
The efficacy of vaccines is boosted by adding these substances to the mix. Examples of these substances that were used in Covid-19 vaccines include aluminum salts and TLR agonists.

Unfortunately, people with compromised immune systems can't get most vaccines. Instead, they must be protected through this effect, which occurs when a large portion of the population is immune from a disease, shielding those who are not protected.
answers: herd immunity [prompt on herd effect or community immunity or population immunity or mass immunity]
answers_formatted: herd immunity [prompt on herd effect or community immunity or population immunity or mass immunity]

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about the cuisine of Hubei, a province in China:
parts: Name this city, the capital of Hubei province and home of the Hubu Xiang Lane, a noted food destination. Reganmian, or hot dry noodles traditionally come from this city.
Because Hubei contains many of these bodies of water, fish are often eaten in Hubei. Other examples of these bodies of water are named after Michigan and Baikal.
Like many other Chinese provinces, Hubei has a variation of this dish. This dish consists of diners dipping raw ingredients such as meat and noodles into boiling soup.
answers: lake [accept Lake Michigan or Lake Baikal]

bonuses.leadin: One of these two gods had his hands cut off by his mother following an action by the other.. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these two gods, who once fought each other in the form of Hippopotami. One of them tricked the other by painting a boat to look like it was made of stone.
Horus and Set competed over who would succeed this god as king. Set had earlier murdered this father of Horus and hidden his body in numerous pieces.
After Isis chopped off Horus's hands, they were retrieved by this god. This crocodile-headed god had a cult-center in the Faiyum region.
answers: Horus AND Seth (accept either order, do not prompt on partial answer)
metadata: accept either order, do not prompt on partial answer

bonuses.leadin: This forester disagreed strenuously with his former protege William Greeley on whether the Forest Service should work against forest fires. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this early conservation icon and first chief of the US Forest Service who frequently feuded with Richard Ballinger. That controversy helped spur the creation of the Progressive Party
Pinchot was appointed head of the US Forest Service by this friend of his. This `bull moose' president founded the Progressive Party
Later, as governor of Pennsylvania, Pinchot supported and helped implement this policy. The Volstead Act enacted this policy.
answers: Theodore Roosevelt [or Teddy Roosevelt; prompt on partial]
prohibition [prompt on temperance or the 18th Amendment]

bonuses.leadin: A theorem named for this mathematician and Edouard Goursat gives criteria under which the integral of a complex-valued function is zero. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this French mathematician. An inequality that states that the dot product of two vectors is less than or equal to the product of their magnitudes is named for this mathematician and Hermann Schwarz.
The Cauchy-Goursat theorem applies only to analytic functions, which have the complex type of this property. It is possible to take the derivative of a function with this property.

The theorem only holds if the region enclosed by the curve being integrated over has the "simple" form of this property, which is stronger than its "path" form. Euler's formula only holds for planar graphs that have this property.
answers: connectedness [accept simply-connected or path-connected or k-connected, I guess]

bonuses.leadin: This piece has inspired more than 100 musical compositions. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this watercolor piece depicting four of a certain animal on top of a hand crank using simplistic line drawings

Paul Klee, the artist of the Twittering Machine, created a surrealist painting titled for the magic of these animals. In a Roy Liechtenstein painting, Donald Duck thinks he has one of these animals at the end of his rod
Klee was often associated with this movement, whose members included Wassily Kandinsky and Franz Marc

bonuses.leadin: These vehicles were first deployed at the Battle of the Somme. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these large armored vehicles which include the T-34 and Abrams. These vehicles typically drive on treads.
This "war of thirst" saw the deployment of the Vickers A tank. This war was fought between two countries led by Daniel Salamanca and Eusebio Ayala over a namesake oil-rich region

Arturo Allessandri, the president of this country, was accused of ignoring volunteers from his country for participating in the Gran Chaco War. His son Jorge Alessandri was also president of this country but was defeated by a Marxist

bonuses.leadin: In a novel, a character describes dancing on the street upon the arrival of this organization, though he later says that this organization does not "let you be human." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this organization which includes a member who executes two people in a former soccer stadium before a crowd. Though that member of this organization injures the narrator with brass knuckles in a fight, he is then injured by a child's slingshot.
Assef joins the Taliban years after raping Hassan in an alley in this novel, which concerns a friend of Hassan's who moved to America.
In the Kite Runner, the Taliban member Assef repeatedly praises this person. This dictator wrote the autobiography Mein Kampf.

bonuses.leadin: This thinker believed that good tendencies in humans could "sprout" into four basic virtues: propriety, wisdom, benevolence, and righteousness. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this ancient philosopher, who demonstrated his belief that humans are innately good with a parable about a child falling down a well.
Mencius was known as the "Second Sage" of the philosophy founded by this ancient Chinese thinker, who believed in the importance of filial piety. His sayings are collected in the Analects.

Confucius believed that disorder came from the incorrect usage of these things, a doctrine called the "rectification of" these things. According to that doctrine, these things must exist in direct correspondence with the real world.
answers: Confucius [accept Kongfuzi or K'ung-fu-tzu or Kongzi]

bonuses.leadin: Before the Tulsa massacre, this event was the deadliest act of terrorism in American history. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 1920 event in which 100 pounds of dynamite in a horse drawn wagon were detonated, killing 30 people. Though the perpetrators of this event have never been caught, it is believed to have been committed by supporters of Luigi Galleani.
Luigi Galleani was a follower of this philosophy, which was popular in the early 20th century with followers such as Emma Goldman as well as Sacco and Vanzetti.
Galleani, Sacco, and Vanzetti were immigrants of this general ethnicity. Immigrants of this ethnicity traveled to the U.S. from cities like Florence or Rome.
answers: Italian anarchism [accept word forms; antiprompt on Galleanists]
answers_formatted: Italian anarchism [ accept word forms; antiprompt on Galleanists]

bonuses.leadin: This pianist has claimed that he took up piano because of the Cat Concerto in Tom and Jerry. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this pianist who played at the opening of the 2008 Summer Olympics in Beijing. He released the album Dragon Songs, which includes the Yellow River Piano Concerto.
Lang Lang is from this country, where the Yellow River Piano Concerto was named after this country's Yellow River.
Lang Lang's father, who supervised his learning of the piano, was a player of this traditional Chinese instrument. This two-stringed spike fiddle is sometimes considered a type of huqin.

bonuses.leadin: The 2020 film The Turning may have a 13% on Rotten Tomatoes, but its original soundtrack was pretty good. For 10 points each:
parts: The film was an adaptation of the 1898 Gothic horror novella The Turn of the Screw by this author of The Wings of the Dove.

This artist contributed the single "Cop Car" to the film's soundtrack. That soundtrack was this artist's first release after the 2018 album Be the Cowboy, which included the songs "Nobody" and "Washing Machine Heart."

This artist wrote "kate's not here," inspired by homelessness in the U.S., for her part of the soundtrack. Other themes in her songs include accidental drownings, mental health struggles, and liking women.
answers: girl in red [accept Marie Ulven Ringheim]

bonuses.leadin: After one character in this play warns Alexandra that she will have to marry her cousin Leo, she is brutally slapped across the face by her husband. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this play. In this play, one character withholds her ailing husband's medication and blackmails her brothers Oscar and Benjamin over stolen railroad bonds to get a larger share in a cotton mill.
This author wrote The Little Foxes. Karen and Martha are accused of having a lesbian affair in this author's play The Children's Hour.
Hellman's Watch On The Rhine ends with the death of a Romanian Nazi collaborator with this title, Teck de Brancovis. A Transylvanian character with this title is the subject of Bram Stoker's Dracula.
answers: count [accept Count Teck de Brancovis or Count Dracula]

bonuses.leadin: The cross-section of this type of scattering is given by 8 pi times r squared over 3. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this type of elastic scattering where electromagnetic waves scatter off of charged particles in a wavelength-independent manner.
J. J. Thomson proposed this model of the nucleus, where negatively charged electrons are situated in a ball of positive charge. This model was disproved in Rutherford's gold foil experiment.
These devices often use the Joule-Thomson effect. These devices pump heat out of their interiors and are often used to keep food cold.

bonuses.leadin: One house designed by this architect features a corner window that swings open in addition to sliding walls in the living room. For 10 points each:
parts: That house, the Schröder house in Utrecht, was designed by this architect who also designed part of the Van Gogh Museum.
Rietveld was a member of this art movement, which was founded by Theo van Doesburg. This art movement mostly used horizontal and vertical lines and primary colors.
Rietveld used the primary colors red and blue to design one of these objects, in addition to a Zig-Zag one of these objects. Eero Saarinen designed a Tulip one of these objects to go with his tables.

bonuses.leadin: One form of this effect arises when the electropositive and highly polarizable bond between carbon and silicon acts as a charge donor. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this effect that can occur when a neighboring carbon atom is replaced with silicon in the beta-silicon effect. It's not the inductive effect, but this effect explains how neighboring alkyl groups stabilize carbocations.

Hyperconjugation lowers the energy of one of these entities for the reaction that forms a carbocation. These entities exist at the maximum of a potential energy diagram for a reaction and are symbolized with a double dagger.
Anions of these elements easily form carbocations since they are good leaving groups. These Group 17 elements include chlorine.

bonuses.leadin: The American Edwin Rist stole numerous feathers and bird skins from the Tring Museum in 2009. For 10 points each:
parts: Rist used the money he earned from selling the feathers to buy this kind of instrument, which opens Morning Mood by Grieg. This woodwind is the larger relative of a piccolo

The Tring museum that Rist stole from started as the private collection of this person, who spent much of his banking family's fortune collecting. This person helped draft the Balfour Declaration, which was addressed to him.

Many of the specimens Rist stole were collected by this biologist, who prompted Charles Darwin to publish On the Origin of Species early because he was also developing a theory of natural selection. A line named for this man divides Indonesia
answers: Lionel Walter Rothschild [accept Lionel Walter Rothschild; prompt on Rothschild]
answers_formatted: Lionel Walter Rothschild [accept Lionel Walter Rothschild; prompt on Rothschild]

bonuses.leadin: After Joseph Kaifa announces that he intends to free Bar-Rabban rather than another character from prison, this character attempts and fails to change his mind. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this character. This character and his dog Banga are tormented by insomnia every single full moon for two thousand years until he is freed by the Master.

In one novel, part of the story of Pontius Pilate is told by this character to Ivan Bezdomny and Mikhail Berlioz. This character predicts the beheading of Berlioz, and his retinue includes the cat Behemoth.
This author invented Professor Woland in his novel The Master and Margarita.
answers: Professor Woland [prompt on Satan or the Devil or synonyms]

bonuses.leadin: One ruler of this house signed the Treaty of Trausnitz with Frederick the Fair, in which he was declared sole Holy Roman Emperor; that didn't stop Pope John XXII from excommunicating him, though. For 10 points each.
parts: Name this house, of which Emperor Louis IV was a member. Members of this house, like the "Mad King" Ludwig II, ruled Bavaria.
Ludwig II of Bavaria is most famous for constructing one of these fortified buildings named Neuschwanstein.

A Wittelsbach ruler of Bohemia with this name was nicknamed "The Winter King" due to the short length of his reign. An earlier emperor with this name was defeated by the Lombard League at the Battle of Legnano.
answers: Frederick [accept Frederick V or Frederick the Winter King; accept Frederick Barbarossa or Frederick I]
answers_formatted: Frederick [accept Frederick V or Frederick the Winter King; accept Frederick Barbarossa or Frederick I]
